Legal_Issue: Whether the respondent met the residency requirement for Canadian citizenship under the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Respondent was physically present in Canada for 567 days and absent for 893 days over a four-year period
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship Judge initially approved the application based on ties to Canada
Remedy_Requested: Minister appealed the approval of the citizenship application
Court_Ruling: Appeal allowed; decision found unreasonable due to inadequate assessment of centralization of mode of living
Claimant_Status: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship
Defendant_Behavior: Absence from Canada for significant periods; claimed residence through connections despite limited physical presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapplication of the residency requirement under the Citizenship Act
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence, centralization of mode of living in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Review by Federal Court of a Citizenship Judge’s decision
Evidence_Used: Duration of physical presence in Canada (567 days), duration of absence (893 days), ties to Canada
Legal_Provision_Cited: Requirement of at least 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years
Application_Basis: Ties to Canada used as basis for approval despite insufficient physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Physical presence records, evidence of familial, economic, and social ties to Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of the Citizenship Judge’s decision and remittal for reconsideration
Governing_Rule: Applicants must accumulate at least 1095 days of residence in Canada over four years; residence may be established by physical presence or centralization of mode of living
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to adequately assess whether the respondent centralized his life in Canada
Outcome: Decision set aside; case remanded to a different Citizenship Judge for reconsideration
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship without meeting法定 residency requirements, undermining integrity of citizenship process
Cause_Description: Minister appealed the Citizenship Judge's approval due to alleged misapplication of residency requirements under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Handling: Federal Court reviewed evidence of presence and absence, but found insufficient analysis of centralization of life
Legal_Provision_Violated: Citizenship Act – Residency requirement (1095 days within four years)
Evidence_Issues: Insufficient evaluation of non-physical indicators of residence such as financial, familial, and social connections
Residency_Compliance: Not met – only 567 days of physical presence recorded
Evidence_Assessment: The Citizenship Judge relied on ties to Canada but did not properly analyze whether the respondent’s life was centralized in Canada
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable because it failed to apply the correct legal test regarding centralization of mode of living
Evidentiary_Issues: Lack of thorough examination of evidence related to centralization of life in Canada
